Overview.Summary: In the 2017 Welsh local elections, Welsh Labour suffered from significant losses nationwide (1,3,9). However, they managed to retain control of Cardiff City Council (1). Jeremy Corbyn, the leader of UK Labour, was mentioned in several articles (2,7). The Welsh European Funding Office examined the strengths and weaknesses of the Welsh labor market (8). Debates over division and union within the party were mentioned (2,9). There was also discussion about Welsh broadband speeds and digital infrastructure (2). There were several articles that provided analyses of the results of the local elections (4,6,10).

Timeline.Text: Welsh Labour MP Louise Haigh retweets a post about division in the Labour party.
Labour retains control of Cardiff City Council in the Welsh local elections.
The Welsh Labour party is shown to have a strong presence in West Wales and the Valleys in terms of employment.
Election forecasts predict that Labour will have a stronger showing in constituencies such as Easington in the 2017 local elections.
Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn is discussed as an important figure in the UK election.
The Labour party, led by Jeremy Corbyn, has strong support in numerous UK constituencies, including Wales.
New head of the Welsh Labour party, Paul Nuttal, calls for improvement in the Welsh and UK labor market.
Welsh Labour suffers losses in the Welsh local elections, causing concern for its future in the Welsh labor market.
Labour party leader Jeremy Corbyn faces criticism from Welsh Labour regarding social care.

Overview.Summary:
The 2017 Welsh local elections, which took place on May 5, saw an increase in seats for the Conservative party and a significant loss for the Labour party (1, 2). Notably, Labour was pushed back by other parties, including Plaid Cymru, in both English and Welsh elections (2). Plaid Cymru was also mentioned as losing some vote share (9).

There were also discussions about the role of Plaid Cymru in Welsh politics, with some speculating on potential alliances and deals with other parties (3, 4). Private innovation in Wales was also a topic of discussion in light of these elections (5).

In terms of national politics, British MPs accused Prime Minister Rajoy of breaching freedom of speech by prosecuting former Catalan politicians (6). Jeremy Corbyn, leader of the Labour party, was expected to perform poorly in the general elections on June 8 (7). There were also discussions about Labour's loss of seats in local elections and the potential for them to form a minority government again (10).

Timeline.Text: Conservatives increase their share by over 550 seats in local elections, while Labour loses over 380.
The Labour Party is predicted to lose hundreds of seats in the upcoming local elections.
The Welsh nationalist Plaid Cymru experiences a decrease in vote share compared to 2015.
Labour and Plaid Cymru form a minority government in the Welsh Assembly.

Overview.Summary: The local elections in the United Kingdom (9). Multiple articles mention the May 4 election date, covering much of England (9,8). The Conservatives win a majority, creating a stable government (5). Labour faces concerns and pushes back (9,8). The United Kingdom is mentioned several times as well (2,9,4).

Timeline.Text: The Welsh Labour Party suffers major losses in the local elections.
Hillary Clinton plans to meet with Belarusian rights activists.
British Prime Minister Theresa May forms an agreement with Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party to support her government.
The Prime Minister's offer on EU citizens living in the UK is confirmed as being independent of the Brexit negotiations.
The Conservatives see a surge in support during the local and mayoral elections.

Overview.Summary: During the 2017 Welsh local elections, the Welsh Labour party led by First Minister Carwyn Jones faced significant challenges (1, 5, 9). The election results showed a shift in support towards the Conservatives and away from Labour (1, 8). Despite losing control in some areas, Labour was able to hold on to some of its strongholds (1, 5). Meanwhile, Welsh Labour distanced itself from the UK party in the midst of the campaign (10), and strategists believed that Carwyn Jones was playing a key role in the election (10).

Timeline.Text: The UK local elections take place and early results indicate that the Conservatives have increased their share of seats by over 550, while Labour loses more than 380.
Labour's leadership, including Jeremy Corbyn, admit that the party had a 'difficult' election and lost control of important councils such as Bridgend, Welsh First Minister Carwyn Jones's stronghold.
Welsh First Minister Carwyn Jones states that money has been found for Northern Ireland in a deal with the DUP, sparking criticism.
Surprising polls reveal a surge in support for Labour, including support in Wales, where the Labour-run Welsh government has been headed by Carwyn Jones since 2009.
First Minister Carwyn Jones and Welsh Labour pledge to focus their campaign on Wales and distance themselves from the UK Labour party, after losses in the local elections.

Overview.Summary: The 2017 Welsh local elections (10) took place in May (1). These elections received letters signed by company employees (3) and had a low turnout, with only 32% of young adults voting (10). The Welsh line was "under siege" during the elections (2). Additionally, there was some controversy over the use of EU funds in Wales and its visibility to voters (7). There were also concerns over cybercrime during the elections (8).

Timeline.Text: Elections in Wales create tensions and result in readership growth for the Sunday Times.
A small Welsh airport becomes an unlikely tech hub.
The deadline to register to vote in the 2017 Welsh local elections is announced.
The Welsh European Funding Office reveals the extent of EU funds spent in Wales.
The BREXIT Dynamics: British and EU27 Challenges after the EU Referendum is published, addressing the impact of BREXIT, in response to Theresa May's snap general election call.
The number of English and Welsh 18-24 year olds estimated to have voted in local elections is reported on.
The Guardian reports on under-taxation by billionaire owned ISPs in Wales.
The Department of Education and Skills in Wales defines citizenship education.
The Grangetown neighbourhood quarterly newsletter reports on political postponements and their impact on local news circulation.
Cybercrime in the context of elections is a key topic in a Welsh university's 'Britain and the EU' themed 'Summer School'.

Overview.Summary: The 2017 Welsh local elections had a significant impact on the Labour party (8) and were forecasted to devastate them (6). Jeremy Corbyn of the Labour party shifted his position to participate in the seven-way TV debate (7). The election included candidates such as Leanne Wood (4,7,10) and she was the leader of Plaid Cymru (1). Her statements as a member of Welsh Assembly suggests that she is a republican (3). Tim Farron, leader of Plaid Cymru, also participated in the TV debate (10), as well as UKIP leader Paul Nuttall, and SNP leader Nicola Sturgeon (7). The local elections also served as a predictor for the general election on June 8th (9). Overall, the articles focus on the various leaders of political parties, particularly Leanne Wood, and their involvement in the local and national elections in Wales.

Timeline.Text: Labour's policies, including those of Jeremy Corbyn, are criticized by a former Labour deputy leader as being 'doomed to failure'.
Voters go to the polls for local elections which are predicted to have a major impact on the Labour party.
In a surprising reversal, Jeremy Corbyn agrees to participate in a leaders' debate ahead of the general election.
A poll points to the possibility of Brexit influencing the upcoming election, with Theresa May and Leanne Wood in the lead.
During the first TV leaders' debate, Leanne Wood corrects Paul Nuttall and criticizes the 'grand fiction' of British general elections.

Overview.Summary: Several articles discuss the 2017 Welsh local elections (1,2,5), which take place on May 5 (10). There is also mention of the low voter turnout for young people in the previous elections (2). The Representation of the People Act 1985 outlines the rules and regulations for these elections (4). The UK Labour party is highlighted as pushing back in these elections (10), and there is mention of consultations for future cycle routes in Wales (8). There is also discussion of the potential impact of these elections on Brexit negotiations (1).

Timeline.Text: A YouGov poll on the Welsh local elections reveals a potential shift in Brexit voting patterns.
Labor suffers losses in the English and Welsh local elections.
The French Presidential elections take place, with the first round of voting.
The first round of the French presidential elections takes place.
James Mackintosh retweets Louise Haigh MP, commenting on the recent problems with superfast internet speeds in a Welsh village.

Overview.Summary: In the 2017 Welsh local elections, Labour retained control of Cardiff City Council (1). However, Labour faced nationwide losses (1) and a "night of gloom" for Jeremy Corbyn (1). The 2016 local elections were also mentioned (5). The local government and parliamentary elections in the UK were discussed (3).The issue of Brexit was also brought up in relation to the elections in the UK (9). One article mentions a Green Party member running for leadership (10). Twitter was mentioned as a platform for left-wing criticism of an interview (8). In terms of regional impact, Scotland and Wales were mentioned in relation to the UK elections (2,3,6)

Timeline.Text: The UK holds local elections, with Welsh labour MP Owen Smith interrupting and shouting down Peter Hitchens during his appearance on This Week.

Labour retains control of Cardiff City Council amid nationwide losses, providing rare good news for Corbyn's leadership, while result in Welsh capital is visible sign of Labour resilience in local elections.
Representatives of local and regional authorities from across the EU meet for the third enlargement days in Brussels.
Labour loses seats across Wales in the general election, and in near-collapse in the Welsh assembly election while their results worsened significantly in local elections.
The running for leadership of the Green Party comes under re-examination.

Overview.Summary: The Welsh local elections of 2017 were highly influential, with the upcoming Brexit and the Cardiff's Grangetown village being below superfast internet connection speeds (1,5). Recent purdah and diversity of Welsh life were main focuses in these elections (3,9). Irish Parliament member James Mackintosh spoke highly of Welsh village connection speeds (4). The Welsh government obeyed building plans (5). Pollster complications, because of word use, bot bullshit software vendors, and Kathy Griffin's trump-severed head mock-up overlap in the election story of 2017 (6).

Timeline.Text: A YouGov poll indicates that the upcoming UK general election will be largely influenced by Brexit.
Twitter users react to news that Russia may have meddled in the US election.
Before local elections, voters are more likely to search for opinion polls than articles from previous local elections.
British Future's annual poll shows that a large majority of Conservative voters want the net migration target to be replaced.

Overview.Summary: In May 2017, local elections were held in Wales, with Welsh Labour retaining control of Cardiff City Council despite suffering nationwide losses (1,7). The elections were seen as an indicator of Brexit voting patterns (6,13,19) and a prediction of the 2017 General Election results (2,3,5,12). The Welsh government had previously urged its citizens to register to vote in the General Election (4). Welsh politicians and party leaders such as Carwyn Jones of the Labour Party and Leanne Wood of Plaid Cymru were mentioned in several articles (5,7,11). The elections also raised discussions about EU funding in Wales (18) and cybercrime related to elections (20). Some articles also referenced age discrepancies in voting turnout (15,16).

Timeline.Text: Cardiff City Council, controlled by Welsh Labour, retains control amid nationwide losses for the party.
The local elections see the Tories gain over 550 seats and Labour loses over 380.
The local elections continue with Labour avoiding possible losses in Wales to Plaid Cymru, Tories, Lib Dems, and UKIP.
Carwyn Jones, Welsh Labour leader, calls snap election to compete with the Tories.
The Combined Authorities (Mayoral Elections) Order 2017 is published, allowing for mayoral elections.
